document_data.name: Ascore
document_data.mainbody: '''Ascore''' was a port city of the [[dwarf|dwarven]] nation of [[Delzoun]] on the northern shores of the [[Narrow Sea]] during the time of the [[Netheril|Netherese Empire]]. However, by the 14th century [[DR]], it was a lonely, windswept ruin on the edge of the [[Anauroch]], near the [[Frozen Sea]], reputed to be haunted by ancient evil.
document_data.Description:
In its heyday, Ascore was a wealthy and bustling port on the Narrow Sea, standing as the gateway to Delzoun. Here dwarves traded with [[elves]] of [[Eaerlann]] and [[Myth Drannor]] and [[human]]s of [[Netheril]] and [[Nimbral]].

In ruins, however, the only sea its docks met was the sea of sand that had half-buried the city. It was a lonely, desolate, and windswept site.
document_data.Geography: By [[1371 DR]], a nameless path led from [[the Fork]] to Ascore, but few but the [[gnome]]s of [[Graevelwood]] ever used it.
document_data.Trade:
Trade goods from Netheril flowed constantly into Delzoun either through the stone docks of Ascore or via the [[Lowroad]], a subterranean highway that connected to Ascore. Ascore received [[gold]] and [[silver]] from the Netherese mining community of [[Bandor Village]] (established in {{Yearlink|-2436}}).

The dwarves also traded with Eaerlann and Nimbral, and with Myth Drannor in [[Cormanthyr]].
document_data.Flora & Fauna: The ruins were sometimes inhabited by desert-dwelling creatures, such as [[pernicon]] and [[dune stalker]]s.
document_data.Inhabitants:
Notably, [[orc]]s avoided the ruins of Ascore, seemingly repelled by some worse evil than they.

A wide variety of [[undead]] were known to populate the ruins.

Adventurers who'd braved the place told that there were also [[hag]]s and that these witches directed undead legions.

From 1372 DR, there was a Shadovar camp in the ruins under the command of a formidable [[archmage]]. While it was only a temporary camp, they remained there for some years.

By the late 15th century [[DR]], the city was claimed as part of the domain of the ancient [[blue dragon]] [[Iymrith|Iymirth]]. Although the dragon was unable to watch over the city because of her own machinations, two of the dragon's offspring, [[Anaxaster]] and [[Chezzaran]], had made separate lairs within a couple of the abandoned stone ships in the harbor. A number of [[gargoyle]]s also inhabited the city.

Locations.Entrance: A millennia-old road ran from the west and into a great door set in a hill, flanked by two massive stone statues of crouching [[griffon]]s with grim aspect. The door opened into a black yawning passage that descended into the earth. Beyond, the road exited the hill and came to the ruins that lay about the base of the cliff that stood above Ascore.
Locations.The Stone Ships: The dwarves built their docks and even their ships wholly of stone, on a characteristically massive scale. These mighty vessels, designed for both trade and warfare and nigh indestructible, plied the Narrow Sea. Up to twenty stone ships could be docked in Ascore at any one time, with thirty or so more out at sea. In the ruined city, these were still visible, half-buried in the sand, with the stone docks standing proudly against the encroaching sea of sand, and the empty hulks of weird stone ships emerging from the dunes to the east. These were the remains of Delzoun's navy.
Locations.The Red Pyramids:
Thirteen tall, pentagonal pyramids stood in a circle in the very center of Ascore, carved all of a strange red stone.) From afar, these were a bizarre landmark for adventurers on the [[The Long Run]] journey along the edge of [[Anauroch]]. Closer to, these grim pyramids were used, so it seemed, by a [[:Category:Covens|
hag covey]] as a focus for casting great [[spell]]s or as a site for rituals enacted in worship of an evil god or a vast and terrible thing dwelling beneath the buried city.The thirteen pyramids are not mentioned in the Ascore write-up in ''[[Netheril: Empire of Magic]]'', suggesting they appeared during or after the dwarves' abandonment of the city after Netheril's fall.

From 1372 DR, a mysterious pool of liquid shadow had appeared in the center of the ring of pyramids. This was in connection to the shade research effort.
Locations.The Hlaungadath Portal: Ascore was the primary, and official, destination of a lost ''[[portal]]'' from [[Hlaungadath]], created to speed travel between the two cities. On a surviving wall in Ascore were inscribed the words of a brief dwarven chant that would activate the ''portal'', only thirty lines long, ending with "that the halls of our fathers may stand for 10,000 years". Speaking this opened the portal in a ruined chamber.{{Cite web/Portals of Anauroch: The Lost Portal at Hlaungadath}}
Locations.The Underdark: The [[Underdark]] under Ascore was special because it connected two domains, the [[Buried Realms]] and the [[Northdark]].

document_data.History:
In {{Yearlink|-3419}}, the Netherese opened trade negotiations with the Delzoun dwarves at Ascore. It took three years, but at last in {{Yearlink|-3416}} they came to agreements. The Netherese built the Lowroad, a trade route through the safest and most secure parts of the Underdark between Ascore and several towns in Netheril.

From {{Yearlink|-2197}}, as archwizards grew to prominence in Netheril, the [[Arctic Rim]] outpost swelled and in turn saw regular desertions. Many of these Netherese deserters went to Ascore to work for the magic-suspicious dwarves rather than serve wizards.

After the collapse of [[Netheril]] ({{Yearlink|-339}}), in the {{YearlinkName|-338}}, [[Netherese]] [[human]]s fled the occupation of [[Runlatha]] and the death of their ruler. Led by a great wizard-warrior known as the [[Beorunna|Bey of Runlatha]] and aided by dwarf [[ranger]]s from Ascore, they journeyed west, through the Lowroad and into Delzoun seeking safety. They continued to migrate west, hoping to settle beyond Delzoun's borders.

As the [[Narrow Sea]] dwindled, the dwarves commenced a gradual withdrawal from Ascore around the [[-333 DR|Year of Humbling Havens, −333 DR]], steadily abandoning the former port city to the sands. 

By [[1370 DR]], the [[Vigilant (Sundarbar)|Vigilant]], a band of [[dwarf]] warriors in [[Sundabar]], west of Ascore, reported that an evil force was rising within the ruined city. They also warned that growing numbers of monsters were coming through the Underdark from the direction of Ascore.

Soon after the return of the [[City of Shade]] at the start of the [[1372 DR|Year of Wild Magic, 1372 DR]], the [[Shadovar]] sent an expedition to Ascore. Though it was unclear what they were doing or why, the Shadovar seemed to be studying the red pyramids. A strange pool of liquid shadow appeared between the pyramids soon after. The shades drove off curious adventurers; a survivor reported on what they'd seen. They remained there for years, until at least [[1375 DR]].
document_data.Rumors & Legends:
Even in the 14th century DR, rumor still claimed that Ascore held much treasure, but also some weird evil that had apparently lingered there two thousand years. It was even whispered that an enormous and wicked entity abided somewhere far under the ruined city.

Scholars did not know the origin or purpose of the thirteen red pyramids. However, they were somehow possibly linked to a similar ring of thirteen dire oaks located in the ruins of [[Karse]].{{Cite web/Candlekeep forum|title=Pyramids under Ascore|author=Jackson Starky|topicid=5851|postid=293561|whichpage=5|date=2010-04-16|accessdate=2017-05-18}}<ref group="note">Fans have speculated on the origin and purpose of the thirteen pyramids and the evil below for a long time. Designers are under a non-disclosure agreement to not reveal the information ({{Cite web/Candlekeep forum|title=Pyramids under Ascore|author=[[George Krashos]]|topicid=5851|postid=118611|whichpage=1|date=2006-01-17|accessdate=2017-05-18}}). One common theory is that the thirteen [[shadevar]]i (not to be confused with the [[Shadovar]]) were imprisoned there ({{Cite web/Candlekeep forum|title=Pyramids under Ascore|author=[[Eric L. Boyd]]|topicid=5851|postid=118648|whichpage=1|date=2006-01-18|accessdate=2017-05-18}}); however, at least three of the shadevari were summoned and destroyed in the ''[[Crypt of the Shadowking]]'' and the ''[[Curse of the Shadowmage]]'' novels, making this theory improbable. Moreover, official sources seemed to deny the theory ({{Cite web/Candlekeep forum|title=Pyramids under Ascore|author=[[George Krashos]]|topicid=5851|postid=271150|whichpage=1|date=2009-07-19|accessdate=2017-05-18}}). As recently as 2015, the truth has still not been revealed ({{Cite web/Candlekeep forum|title=Pyramids under Ascore|author=[[George Krashos]]|topicid=5851|postid=462861|whichpage=8|date=2015-01-09|accessdate=2017-05-18}}); however, [[Ed Greenwood]] did admit that the pyramids were possibly related to the thirteen dire oaks found in [[Karse]] ({{Cite web/Candlekeep forum|title=Pyramids under Ascore|author=Jackson Starky|topicid=5851|postid=293561|whichpage=5|date=2010-04-16|accessdate=2017-05-18}}).
